docs.title: BlockBall Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation for BlockBall - the ultimate soccer/football plugin for Minecraft servers!

docs.title: What is BlockBall?
docs.text: BlockBall is a powerful Spigot plugin that brings authentic soccer/football gameplay to your Minecraft server. Whether you want to create a casual lobby game or a competitive tournament experience, BlockBall provides all the tools you need.

docs.title: Core Gameplay
docs.text:
• Interactive Soccer Ball: Realistic ball physics without requiring any resource packs
  • Customizable Physics Engine: Fine-tune ball behavior to match your server's style
  • Multiple Game Modes: Hub games, minigames, and referee-controlled matches

docs.title: Server Integration
docs.text:
• PlaceholderAPI Support: Full integration for scoreboards and displays
  • Cross-Platform Compatibility: Works with Bukkit, Paper, and Folia
  • Multiple Arenas: Run unlimited concurrent games on your server
  • Bedrock Support: Compatible with Bedrock clients via GeyserMC

docs.title: Advanced Features
docs.text:
• Player Statistics: Track goals, wins, and performance (Patreon feature)
  • Referee System: Full match control for tournaments and events (Patreon feature)
  • Team Management: Automatic team balancing and custom team configurations
  • Flexible Permissions: Granular control over player access

docs.title: Developer API
docs.text:
BlockBall provides a comprehensive Developer API that allows other plugins to integrate with and extend BlockBall's functionality. Whether you want to create custom game modes, track statistics, or build tournament systems, the API gives you the tools you need.

Installation Notice

The BlockBall API is not currently published to Maven Central or other distribution systems. You must directly reference the BlockBall.jar file as a dependency in your development environment.

docs.title: Plugin Dependencies
docs.text:
Add BlockBall as a soft dependency in your plugin.yml:

softdepend: [ BlockBall ]

Why Soft Dependency?

Using softdepend ensures your plugin loads properly even if BlockBall isn't installed, allowing you to handle the integration gracefully.

docs.title: API Access
docs.text: The BlockBall API is accessed through Bukkit's Service Manager. All core services are registered automatically when BlockBall loads.

docs.title: SoccerBallFactory
docs.text:
Create and manage soccer balls independent of games.

Key Features: - Create soccer balls at any location - Configure ball physics and behavior - Control ball movement and interactions

docs.title: GameService
docs.text:
Manage BlockBall games and player participation.

Key Features: - Access existing games by name - Add/remove players from teams - Monitor game states and events - Control game flow programmatically

docs.title: Creating Independent Soccer Balls
docs.text:
Use the SoccerBallFactory to spawn soccer balls outside of game contexts:

public class YourPlugin extends JavaPlugin {
    @Override
    public void onEnable() {
        Player player = Bukkit.getPlayer("YourPlayerName");

        // Creating a soccer ball independent of a game.
        SoccerBallFactory soccerBallFactory = Bukkit.getServicesManager().load(SoccerBallFactory.class);
        SoccerBall soccerBall = soccerBallFactory.createSoccerBall(player.getLocation(), new SoccerBallSettings());
        // The is no way to directly set the velocity, but you can kick it relative to the position the player.
        soccerBall.kickByPlayer(player);

        // Letting a player join a game.
        GameService gameService = Bukkit.getServicesManager().load(GameService.class);
        SoccerGame game = gameService.getByName("myGameName");
        game.join(player, Team.BLUE);
    }
}

docs.title: Bedrock Edition Support

BlockBall fully supports cross-platform gameplay between Java Edition and Bedrock Edition clients (mobile, console, Windows 10/11) through GeyserMC. This allows players on any device to enjoy BlockBall together!

Cross-Platform Compatibility

Bedrock players can join Java servers running BlockBall using GeyserMC, enabling true cross-platform soccer matches between PC, mobile, and console players.

docs.title: Command Reference
docs.text:
BlockBall provides a comprehensive set of commands for arena management, gameplay, and administration. All commands require the appropriate permissions.

Getting Help

Access the in-game help system anytime: 

/blockball help 1

docs.title: /blockball create
docs.text:
Creates a new arena from scratch.

/blockball create <name> <displayName>

Parameters: - name - Unique identifier for the arena (no spaces) - displayName - User-friendly name (supports color codes)

Example: 

/blockball create stadium1 &6Golden Stadium

docs.title: /blockball copy
docs.text:
Duplicates an existing arena with all its settings.

/blockball copy <source> <name> <displayName>

Parameters: - source - Name of existing arena to copy - name - New arena identifier - displayName - Display name for the new arena

Example: 

/blockball copy stadium1 stadium2 &bBlue Stadium

docs.title: /blockball delete
docs.text:
Permanently removes an arena and its configuration.

/blockball delete <name>

Destructive Action

This action cannot be undone. Make sure to backup your arena files if needed.

docs.title: /blockball list
docs.text:
Shows all arenas and their current status.

/blockball list [player]

Output Example: 

stadium1 [Golden Stadium] [enabled]
arena2 [Practice Field] [disabled]

docs.title: /blockball toggle
docs.text:
Enables or disables an arena.

/blockball toggle <name>
  • Enabled: Players can join and play
  • Disabled: Arena is inaccessible to players

docs.title: /blockball join
docs.text:
Join a specific game, optionally choosing a team.

/blockball join <name> [team] [player]

Parameters: - name - Arena name to join - team - red, blue, or referee (optional) - player - Target player (admin only)

Examples: 

/blockball join stadium1
/blockball join stadium1 red
/blockball join stadium1 blue Steve

docs.title: /blockball leave
docs.text:
Leave the current game.

/blockball leave [player]

docs.title: /blockball axe
docs.text:
Get the selection tool for marking areas.

/blockball axe

Usage: - Left-click: Select first corner (Point A) - Right-click: Select second corner (Point B)

docs.title: /blockball select
docs.text:
Apply your axe selection to define arena areas.

/blockball select <name> <type>

Area Types: - field - Main playing area - red_goal - Red team's goal - blue_goal - Blue team's goal

Example: 

/blockball select stadium1 field

docs.title: /blockball location
docs.text:
Set specific points using your current position.

/blockball location <name> <type>

Location Types: - ball - Where the ball spawns - red_spawnpoint - Red team spawn - blue_spawnpoint - Blue team spawn - red_lobby - Red team lobby (minigames) - blue_lobby - Blue team lobby (minigames) - referee_spawnpoint - Referee position - referee_lobby - Referee lobby - leave_spawnpoint - Where players go when leaving

docs.title: /blockball highlight
docs.text:
Toggle visual boundaries for easier arena editing.

/blockball highlight <name>

Shows particle effects or blocks around defined areas.

docs.title: /blockball inventory
docs.text:
Copy your current inventory as the team's default gear.

/blockball inventory <name> <team>

Teams: red or blue

docs.title: /blockball armor
docs.text:
Copy your current armor as the team's default equipment.

/blockball armor <name> <team>

docs.title: /blockball gamerule
docs.text:
Modify arena settings and game mechanics.

/blockball gamerule <key> <name> <value>

Common Game Rules: - gameType - hubgame, minigame, or refereegame - maxScore - Points needed to win - duration - Game length in seconds

Example: 

/blockball gamerule gameType stadium1 minigame

docs.title: 🛡️ Referee Commands (Patreon Feature)
docs.text: Control match flow during tournaments and events.

docs.title: Game Control
docs.text: Command Description /blockball referee startgame Start lobby countdown /blockball referee stop End current period/game /blockball referee whistleresume Resume play, enable ball /blockball referee whistlestop Pause game, disable ball /blockball referee freezetime Freeze timer and ball /blockball referee nextperiod Move to next game period

docs.title: Ball Control
docs.text: Command Description /blockball referee setball [x] [y] [z] [yaw] [pitch] [world] Teleport ball to position /blockball referee setballrel [forward] [sideward] Set ball relative to referee

docs.title: Player Management
docs.text: Command Description /blockball referee yellowcard <player> Give yellow card /blockball referee redcard <player> Give red card /blockball referee kickplayer <player> Remove player from game

docs.title: /blockball sign
docs.text:
Create interactive signs for easy player access.

/blockball sign <name> <type>

Sign Types: - join - Join any available team - leave - Leave current game - team_red - Join red team specifically - team_blue - Join blue team specifically

Usage: 1. Run the command 2. Right-click any sign to convert it

docs.title: /blockball placeholder
docs.text:
Test placeholder values for scoreboards and displays.

/blockball placeholder <placeholder>

Example: 

/blockball placeholder %blockball_game_redScore%

docs.title: /blockball reload
docs.text:
Reload arena configurations without restarting.

/blockball reload [name]
  • No name: Reload all arenas
  • With name: Reload specific arena

docs.title: 💡 Pro Tips
docs.text:
Command Efficiency

  • Use tab completion to see available options
  • Most commands support partial arena name matching
  • Commands are case-insensitive for convenience

Permission Requirements

  • Regular players need blockball.command for basic commands
  • Arena editing requires blockball.edit
  • Referee commands need blockball.referee.join

Admin Features

Many commands accept a player parameter when you have admin permissions, allowing you to manage other players' arena participation.

docs.title: Advanced Customization
docs.text: Take your BlockBall arenas to the next level with extensive customization options. This guide covers everything from basic tweaks to advanced configurations using AI assistance.

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text: BlockBall offers hundreds of configuration options through arena YAML files. These files control everything from game mechanics to visual effects, allowing you to create unique gameplay experiences.

docs.title: Location
docs.text:
All arena customizations are stored in YAML files located at: 

/plugins/BlockBall/arena/<arena_name>.yml

For example, if your arena is named game1, the file will be: 

/plugins/BlockBall/arena/game1.yml

docs.title: Editing Workflow
docs.text:
1. Stop the arena: /blockball toggle <arena_name> (if enabled)
  2. Edit the YAML file using your preferred text editor
  3. Apply changes: /blockball reload <arena_name>
  4. Test your changes in-game

Text Editor Recommendations

  • Notepad++ (Windows) - Free with YAML syntax highlighting
  • Visual Studio Code - Cross-platform with excellent YAML support
  • Sublime Text - Lightweight with good plugin support

docs.title: Using ChatGPT for Easy Setup
docs.text: BlockBall's configuration files contain hundreds of options with detailed comments. Instead of learning every setting manually, you can use AI to make precise changes quickly and accurately.

docs.title: Step-by-Step Process
docs.text:
1. Upload your arena file to ChatGPT
  2. Describe your desired changes in plain English
  3. Review the AI suggestions before applying
  4. Apply changes manually to your file (recommended for safety)

docs.text:

"Make the game last 10 minutes with 5-minute halftime"
"Increase ball speed by 50% and make it bounce higher"
"Add a 30-second lobby countdown before games start"

Advanced Customizations:

docs.title: AI Safety Tips
docs.text:
Backup First

Always backup your arena files before applying AI-generated changes.

Manual Application

While ChatGPT can generate download links, manually applying suggested changes ensures file integrity and gives you better understanding.

Verification

After applying changes, use /blockball reload and test thoroughly before going live.

docs.title: Creating Your First Soccer Arena
docs.text: This comprehensive guide will walk you through setting up a BlockBall soccer arena from start to finish. By the end, you'll have a fully functional game ready for players to enjoy!

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text: Creating a BlockBall arena involves: 1. Basic Setup - Create the game and define play areas 2. Team Configuration - Set goals and spawn points 3. Game Activation - Enable and test your arena 4. Optional Enhancements - Add advanced features

docs.title: Step 1: Create Your Game
docs.text:
First, create a new arena configuration file:

/blockball create game1 My first game

Pro Tip

You can copy settings from an existing arena instead: 

/blockball copy existing_game new_game My new game

docs.title: Step 2: Verify Creation
docs.text:
Check that your game was created successfully:

/blockball list

Expected Output: 

game1 [My first game] [disabled]

✅ Success! Your arena exists but is disabled (normal for new arenas).

docs.title: Step 3: Get Setup Tools
docs.text:
Obtain the selection tool for marking areas:

/blockball axe

Enable visual highlighting to see areas while editing:

/blockball highlight game1

Visual Aid

Highlighting makes boundaries visible with particles/blocks, making setup much easier!

docs.title: Step 4: Mark the Playing Field
docs.text:
The playing field is where all soccer action happens.

  1. Select Corner A: Left-click with the axe
  2. Select Corner B: Right-click with the axe
  3. Apply Selection: Run the command
/blockball select game1 field

Important

Make sure your field is large enough for players to move around comfortably!

docs.title: Step 5: Set Team Goals
docs.text: Each team needs a goal area where points are scored.

docs.title: Red Team Goal
docs.text:
1. Select the goal area with your axe (left-click + right-click)
  2. Apply the selection:
/blockball select game1 red_goal

docs.title: Blue Team Goal
docs.text:
1. Select the opposite goal area
  2. Apply the selection:
/blockball select game1 blue_goal

docs.title: Step 6: Set Ball Spawn Point
docs.text:
Position yourself where you want the ball to appear when the game starts:

/blockball location game1 ball

Best Practice

Place the ball spawn at the center of your field for fair play.

docs.title: Step 7: Enable the Arena
docs.text:
Once all areas are defined, activate your game:

/blockball toggle game1

docs.title: Step 8: Verify Success
docs.text:
Confirm your arena is now active:

/blockball list

Expected Output: 

game1 [My first game] [enabled]

🎉 Congratulations! Your basic arena is ready!

docs.title: Step 9: Test Your Arena
docs.text: Players can now join in two ways: - Walk into the field - Automatic join - Use command: /blockball join game1

docs.title: Set Leave Spawn Point
docs.text:
Prevent players from being teleported to random locations:

/blockball location game1 leave_spawnpoint

docs.title: Configure Team Spawn Points
docs.text:
Give teams dedicated starting positions:

# Temporarily disable to enter the field
/blockball toggle game1

# Set team positions
/blockball location game1 red_spawnpoint
/blockball location game1 blue_spawnpoint

# Re-enable the game
/blockball toggle game1

docs.title: 🏆 Create a Minigame Mode
docs.text: Transform your arena into a structured minigame with lobbies and time limits.

docs.title: Step 10: Convert to Minigame
docs.text:
/blockball gamerule gameType game1 minigame

Error Messages

If you see errors, don't worry! We'll fix them in the next steps.

docs.title: Step 11: Set Lobby Spawn Points
docs.text:
Players need somewhere to wait before games start:

/blockball location game1 red_lobby
/blockball location game1 blue_lobby

docs.title: Step 12: Final Activation
docs.text:
Enable your completed minigame:

/blockball toggle game1

docs.title: Advanced Interactions & Integration
docs.text: BlockBall provides extensive customization options for player interactions, permissions, and integration with other plugins. This guide covers everything from basic command restrictions to complex permission-based workflows.

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text:
While BlockBall includes built-in settings for common restrictions (commands, block breaking, game modes), you can create sophisticated interaction systems using:

  • Custom Commands: Execute actions when players join/leave games
  • Permission-Based Control: Dynamic permission changes during gameplay
  • Region Integration: Area-based restrictions and protections
  • External Plugin Hooks: Integration with economy, chat, and other systems

docs.title: Basic Command Setup
docs.text:
Execute custom commands automatically when players join or leave games by editing your arena configuration file:

File Location: /plugins/BlockBall/arena/<arena_name>.yml

# Commands executed when players join
joinCommands:
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/say Welcome %blockball_player_name% to the arena!'
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/gamemode adventure %blockball_player_name%'
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/experience add %blockball_player_name% 1'

# Commands executed when players leave  
leaveCommands:
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/say Goodbye %blockball_player_name%!'
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/gamemode survival %blockball_player_name%'
  - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
    command: '/heal %blockball_player_name%'

docs.title: Command Types
docs.text:
Type Description Use Case SERVER_PER_PLAYER Execute with server permissions Commands players don't have permission for PER_PLAYER Execute with player permissions Commands the player could run themselves

Permission Levels

Use SERVER_PER_PLAYER for administrative commands (gamemode, teleport, etc.) and PER_PLAYER for actions the player should be able to do themselves.

docs.title: Team-Specific Commands
docs.text:
Configure different commands for each team:

# Red team join commands
teams:
  red:
    joinCommands:
      - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
        command: '/kit red_team %blockball_player_name%'
      - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'  
        command: '/effect give %blockball_player_name% strength 999999 0'
    leaveCommands:
      - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
        command: '/clear %blockball_player_name%'

# Blue team join commands  
  blue:

docs.title: Permission System
docs.text: BlockBall uses a comprehensive permission system to control player access to features and commands. This guide helps you configure permissions correctly for different user roles on your server.

docs.title: 🎯 Permission Levels Overview
docs.text: BlockBall permissions are organized into three main levels:

docs.title: 🟢 User Level
docs.text: Who gets this: All players who should be able to play BlockBall Purpose: Basic gameplay functionality

docs.title: 🟡 Admin/User Level
docs.text: Who gets this: Trusted players or staff members Purpose: Enhanced features that could be abused if given to everyone Caution: Review carefully before granting to regular players

docs.title: 🔴 Admin Level
docs.text: Who gets this: Server administrators and staff only Purpose: Arena management and server administration

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Setup (Recommended Permissions)
docs.text: For most servers, these permissions provide the best balance of functionality and security:

docs.title: Essential Player Permissions
docs.text:
# Basic BlockBall access (required for all players)
- blockball.command
- blockball.join.*

# Display permissions (recommended for all players)  
- blockball.shyscoreboard.scoreboard.*
- blockball.shybossbar.bossbar.*

docs.title: Admin Permissions
docs.text:
# Arena management (staff only)
- blockball.edit
- blockball.referee.join

# System administration (staff only)
- blockball.shyscoreboard.command
- blockball.shyscoreboard.reload
- blockball.shybossbar.command  
- blockball.shybossbar.reload
- blockball.shycommandsigns.command
- blockball.shycommandsigns.add
- blockball.shycommandsigns.reload

docs.title: Core Gameplay Permissions
docs.text:
Permission Level Description blockball.command User Access to /blockball command base blockball.join.* User Join any arena (requires blockball.command) blockball.join.[arena_name] User Join specific arena only

Example Arena-Specific Permissions: 

# Allow joining only "stadium1" arena
- blockball.join.stadium1

# Allow joining multiple specific arenas  
- blockball.join.stadium1
- blockball.join.arena2
- blockball.join.tournament

docs.title: Administrative Permissions
docs.text: Permission Level Description blockball.edit Admin Create, modify, and delete arenas blockball.referee.join Admin Access referee mode and commands

docs.title: Enhanced Player Permissions
docs.text:
Permission Level Description blockball.command.staff Admin/User Execute commands while in-game blockball.game.inventory Admin/User Open/use inventories during games

Legacy Permissions

blockball.command.staff and blockball.game.inventory are legacy permissions that will be replaced in future versions. Use with caution.

docs.title: Security Guidelines

Admin Permission Security

  • Never give blockball.edit to regular players

docs.title: Performance Optimization

  • Create permission groups rather than individual assignments
  • Test permission changes on a development server first

docs.title: User Experience
docs.text:
Player-Friendly Setup

  • Grant scoreboard and boss bar permissions to all players
  • Use descriptive group names that make sense to your staff
  • Document your permission structure for other administrators

- "&7Games: &f%blockball_player_games%"

docs.title: 🔍 Testing Placeholders
docs.text:
Use the built-in command to test placeholder values:

/blockball placeholder %blockball_game_redScore%
/blockball placeholder %blockball_player_name%

This helps verify that placeholders are working correctly and returning expected values.

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: Problem Solution Placeholder shows as text Install PlaceholderAPI Empty/null values Check arena name suffix for external plugins Outdated information Use /blockball reload to refresh Statistics not working Requires Patreon version

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Performance

  • Avoid excessive placeholder usage in high-frequency updates
  • Cache placeholder values when possible
  • Use specific placeholders rather than checking everything

Formatting

  • Placeholders return raw values - apply formatting in your display system
  • Color codes work in displayName placeholders
  • Numeric values can be formatted using your scoreboard/chat plugin

This comprehensive placeholder system allows you to create rich, dynamic displays that enhance the BlockBall experience for your players!

docs.title: Referee System (Patreon Feature)
docs.text:
The BlockBall referee system transforms your server into a professional soccer venue with complete match control. Perfect for tournaments, events, and competitive gameplay where you need human oversight and precise game management.

Premium Feature

The referee system is exclusive to Patreon supporters who have funded this advanced feature. Support development to access these professional-grade tools! ❤️

docs.title: 🎯 What is Referee Mode?
docs.text: Referee mode gives a designated admin or moderator complete control over match flow using specialized commands. Instead of automatic game progression, referees manage every aspect of the game manually.

docs.title: Key Capabilities
docs.text:
• Match Control: Start, pause, and stop games at will
  • Ball Management: Place the ball anywhere on the field
  • Time Control: Freeze time, skip periods, manage countdowns
  • Player Discipline: Issue yellow/red cards and manage ejections
  • Professional Feel: Creates authentic tournament atmosphere

docs.title: Perfect For
docs.text:
• Server Events: Special tournaments and competitions
  • Streaming: Controlled matches for content creation
  • Training: Teaching new players proper soccer mechanics
  • Competitions: Prize tournaments requiring human oversight

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Before setting up referee mode, ensure you have: 1. Patreon subscription for BlockBall 2. Working minigame arena (complete the basic setup first) 3. Proper permissions configured for referees

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Standard Minigame Arena
docs.text:
Required Foundation

You must start with a working minigame arena before converting to referee mode. Follow the game creation guide completely first.

Ensure your arena has all required elements: - ✅ Playing field defined - ✅ Both team goals set - ✅ Ball spawn point configured - ✅ Team spawn points established - ✅ Lobby spawn points configured - ✅ Arena enabled and tested

docs.title: Step 2: Set Referee Positions
docs.text:
Field Referee Position Position yourself where the referee should spawn during active gameplay: 

/blockball location game1 referee_spawnpoint

Lobby Referee Position Move to where the referee should wait during lobby phase: 

/blockball location game1 referee_lobby

Positioning Tips

  • Field position: Center of field or sideline for best visibility
  • Lobby position: Elevated platform or special area separate from players

docs.title: Step 3: Convert to Referee Game
docs.text:
Transform your minigame into a referee-controlled match: 

/blockball gamerule gameType game1 refereegame

docs.title: Step 4: Enable and Test
docs.text:
Activate your referee arena: 

/blockball toggle game1

Verify the conversion worked: 

/blockball list

Expected Output: 

game1 [My first game] [enabled] [refereegame]

docs.title: Player Join Process
docs.text:
Players join normally using existing methods: 

/blockball join game1 red
/blockball join game1 blue

Referee Required

The lobby countdown will NOT start until a referee joins the game.

docs.title: Referee Join
docs.text:
A qualified admin joins as referee: 

/blockball join game1 referee

Required Permission: blockball.referee.join

docs.title: Match Initiation
docs.text:
Once ready, the referee starts the game: 

/blockball referee startgame

This begins the lobby countdown and transitions to active gameplay.

docs.title: Game Flow Control
docs.text: Command Purpose Usage /blockball referee startgame Begin lobby countdown Use when all players are ready /blockball referee stop End current period/game Transitions to final period on first use, stops completely on second /blockball referee nextperiod Skip to next configured period Useful for half-time transitions

docs.title: Match State Management
docs.text: Command Purpose Effect /blockball referee whistleresume Resume active play Ball becomes interactable, time resumes /blockball referee whistlestop Pause active play Ball becomes inactive, players can't interact /blockball referee freezetime Freeze game timer Stops countdown while keeping ball inactive

docs.title: Ball Positioning
docs.text:
Command Purpose Parameters /blockball referee setball [x] [y] [z] [yaw] [pitch] [world] Teleport ball to exact coordinates Optional: specify exact position /blockball referee setballrel [forward] [sideward] Position ball relative to referee Forward/sideward distance from referee

Examples: 

# Place ball at referee's feet
/blockball referee setball

# Position ball 5 blocks forward, 2 blocks right
/blockball referee setballrel 5 2

# Exact coordinates for penalty kicks
/blockball referee setball 100 65 200 0 0 world

docs.title: Card Management
docs.text:
Issue cards to track player behavior and infractions:

# Yellow card for minor infractions
/blockball referee yellowcard <player>

# Red card for major infractions  
/blockball referee redcard <player>

docs.title: Player Ejection
docs.text:
Remove disruptive players from the match: 

/blockball referee kickplayer <player>

Manual Tracking

The referee system displays cards but doesn't automatically eject players for accumulating cards. Referees must manually track infractions and eject players as needed.

docs.title: Card Display Integration
docs.text:
Show player cards on scoreboards by editing your scoreboard configuration:

File: /plugins/BlockBall/scoreboard/blockball_scoreboard.yml

# Add to scoreboard lines
lines:
  - "Cards: %blockball_player_cardDisplay%"
  # Or show individual counts
  - "%blockball_player_redCards% Red, %blockball_player_yellowCards% Yellow"

Visual Examples: - 🟨🟨🟥 - Two yellow cards, one red card - 2 Red, 1 Yellow - Numerical display

docs.title: Whistle Sound Integration
docs.text: Create an authentic referee experience with whistle sounds:

docs.title: Setup Process
docs.text:
1. Install a Command Items plugin (search "Command Items" on SpigotMC)
  2. Bind referee commands to items in your inventory
  3. Add whistle sounds using /playsound commands
  4. Set referee inventory to include these items automatically

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
# In your command items plugin config
referee_whistle:
  item: "TRIPWIRE_HOOK"
  name: "&6Referee Whistle"
  commands:
    - "/playsound entity.player.levelup master @a ~ ~ ~ 1.0 2.0"
    - "/blockball referee whistleresume"

referee_stop:
  item: "BARRIER"  
  name: "&cStop Play"
  commands:
    - "/playsound block.note_block.bass master @a ~ ~ ~ 1.0 0.5"
    - "/blockball referee whistlestop"

docs.title: Apply to Referee Inventory
docs.text:
# Give yourself the items, then save as referee inventory
/blockball inventory game1 referee

docs.title: Custom Referee Announcements
docs.text:
Enhance the experience with professional announcements:

# Add to arena configuration
refereeCommands:
  goalScored:
    - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
      command: '/playsound entity.firework_rocket.blast master @a'
    - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'  
      command: '/broadcast &6GOAL! &f%blockball_player_name% scores for %blockball_player_teamDisplayName%!'

  cardIssued:
    - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
      command: '/playsound block.anvil.land master @a'
    - type: 'SERVER_PER_PLAYER'
      command: '/broadcast &e%blockball_player_name% receives a card from the referee!'

docs.title: Match Day Workflow
docs.text:
1. Pre-Match Setup
  2. Referees join and verify arena state
  3. Test whistle commands and ball positioning

  4. Confirm scoreboard and announcement systems

  5. Player Registration

  6. Teams join their respective sides
  7. Referee verifies team compositions

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Referee Guidelines

  • Communicate clearly: Use chat to explain decisions to players
  • Be consistent: Apply rules fairly to both teams
  • Stay neutral: Maintain impartial positioning and decisions
  • Know the commands: Practice referee commands before live matches

Technical Tips

  • Test everything: Run practice matches before important events
  • Have backups: Train multiple referees for coverage

docs.title: Interactive Signs
docs.text: Create user-friendly join and leave signs that allow players to interact with BlockBall arenas through simple right-clicks. This guide covers everything from basic sign creation to advanced customization.

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text: BlockBall signs provide an intuitive way for players to join games without memorizing commands. Players simply right-click signs to join arenas, switch teams, or leave games.

docs.title: Sign Types Available
docs.text:
• Join Signs: Join any available team automatically
  • Leave Signs: Exit the current game
  • Team-Specific Signs: Join a specific team (Red/Blue)
  • Custom Signs: Advanced configurations for special needs

docs.title: Step 1: Place a Sign
docs.text: Place any type of sign block in your world where you want players to interact.

docs.title: Step 2: Choose Sign Type
docs.text:
Execute the appropriate command for your desired sign functionality:

# General join sign (auto-assigns team)
/blockballsign add blockball_join_sign arena <game_name>

# Leave game sign
/blockballsign add blockball_leave_sign arena <game_name>

# Team-specific join signs
/blockballsign add blockball_join_red_sign arena <game_name>
/blockballsign add blockball_join_blue_sign arena <game_name>

docs.title: Step 3: Apply to Sign
docs.text: Right-click the sign you placed. The sign will automatically update with BlockBall formatting and functionality.

docs.title: Practical Examples
docs.text:
# Example: Create join sign for "stadium1" arena
/blockballsign add blockball_join_sign arena stadium1

# Example: Create red team sign for tournament arena
/blockballsign add blockball_join_red_sign arena tournament_final

# Example: Create leave sign (works for any game)
/blockballsign add blockball_leave_sign arena stadium1

docs.title: General Join Sign
docs.text:
Command: /blockballsign add blockball_join_sign arena <game>

Functionality: - Joins any available team automatically - Balances teams when possible - Shows current game status

Best For: Main entrances, lobby areas

docs.title: Leave Sign
docs.text:
Command: /blockballsign add blockball_leave_sign arena <game>

Functionality: - Removes player from current game - Works regardless of which arena they're in - Safe exit from any BlockBall game

Best For: Exit areas, spawn points

docs.title: Red Team Join
docs.text:
Command: /blockballsign add blockball_join_red_sign arena <game>

Functionality: - Joins red team specifically - Shows red team status and availability - May reject if team is full

docs.title: Blue Team Join
docs.text:
Command: /blockballsign add blockball_join_blue_sign arena <game>

Functionality: - Joins blue team specifically - Shows blue team status and availability - May reject if team is full

Best For: Team selection areas, faction-based servers

docs.title: Removing Signs
docs.text: Simply break the sign with your hand or any tool. The BlockBall functionality will be automatically removed.

docs.title: Editing Signs
docs.text: To modify an existing sign: 1. Break the current sign 2. Place a new sign in the desired location 3. Run the appropriate command again 4. Right-click the new sign to apply

docs.title: Bulk Sign Creation
docs.text:
For large projects, you can create multiple signs efficiently:

# Create multiple join signs for the same arena
/blockballsign add blockball_join_sign arena stadium1
# Right-click first sign
# Right-click second sign  
# Right-click third sign...

Efficiency Tip

After running a sign command, you can right-click multiple signs to apply the same configuration to all of them.

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text:
BlockBall uses an internal version of ShyCommandSigns for sign functionality. You can customize appearance and behavior through configuration files.

Configuration Location: /plugins/BlockBall/sign/

docs.title: Edit Sign Text
docs.text:
Modify the sign templates in the configuration folder:

# Example: /plugins/BlockBall/sign/blockball_join_sign.yml
template:
  line1: "&6[BlockBall]"
  line2: "%arena_displayName%"
  line3: "&7Click to Join!"
  line4: "&a%arena_players%/%arena_maxPlayers%"

docs.title: Apply Changes
docs.text:
After editing configuration files: 

/blockballsign reload
# OR
/blockball reload

docs.title: Dynamic Sign Content
docs.text:
# Show different text based on game state
template:
  line1: "&6[BlockBall]"
  line2: "%arena_displayName%"
  line3: "%arena_state_display%"
  line4: "&7%arena_players%/%arena_maxPlayers%"

# Custom state messages
states:
  JOINABLE: "&aClick to Join!"
  RUNNING: "&eGame in Progress"
  DISABLED: "&cArena Closed"

docs.title: Team-Specific Styling
docs.text:
# Red team sign customization
red_team_template:
  line1: "&c&l[RED TEAM]"
  line2: "%arena_displayName%"
  line3: "&7Join the Fire!"
  line4: "&c%red_players%/%red_maxPlayers% players"

# Blue team sign customization  
blue_team_template:
  line1: "&9&l[BLUE TEAM]"
  line2: "%arena_displayName%"
  line3: "&7Join the Water!"
  line4: "&9%blue_players%/%blue_maxPlayers% players"

docs.title: Interactive Effects
docs.text:
# Add particle effects and sounds
effects:
  click_sound: "entity.experience_orb.pickup"
  success_sound: "entity.player.levelup"
  failure_sound: "entity.villager.no"

particles:
  success: "VILLAGER_HAPPY"
  failure: "VILLAGER_ANGRY"

docs.title: Central Hub Layout
docs.text:
[Leave]
      |
[Red] [Join] [Blue]
      |

docs.text:
[Stadium 1] [Stadium 2] [Stadium 3]
[Join Red]  [Join Blue] [Leave All]

docs.title: At Arena Entrance
docs.text:
• Join sign: Main entry point
  • Team selection: Red and Blue options
  • Information: Arena rules or status

docs.title: Inside Arena
docs.text:
• Leave signs: Multiple exit points
  • Team switch: Allow mid-game team changes (if enabled)

docs.title: Spawn Area Integration
docs.text:
• Return signs: Easy access back to arenas
  • Status displays: Show all arena states

docs.title: Multi-Arena Signs
docs.text:
Create signs that work with multiple arenas:

# Configuration for multi-arena sign
multi_arena_sign:
  arenas:
    - stadium1
    - stadium2  
    - tournament
  behavior: "join_first_available"
  template:
    line1: "&6[BlockBall]"
    line2: "&7Quick Join"
    line3: "&aAny Arena"
    line4: "&7Click to play!"

docs.title: Conditional Signs
docs.text:
Signs that appear only under certain conditions:

# VIP-only signs
vip_sign:
  permission: "blockball.vip"
  template:
    line1: "&6&l[VIP]"
    line2: "&7Exclusive Arena"
    line3: "&eVIP Members Only"
    line4: "&7Click to join!"

docs.text:
Create dynamic, updating signs:

animated_join:
  animation:
    frames:
      - "&6>>> &lJOIN &6<<<"
      - "&e>>> &lJOIN &e<<<"
      - "&a>>> &lJOIN &a<<<"
    speed: 20  # ticks between frames

docs.title: Scoreboard Integration
docs.text:
# Sign that shows live match data
live_scoreboard_sign:
  template:
    line1: "%arena_displayName%"
    line2: "&c%red_score% &7- &9%blue_score%"
    line3: "&7Time: %time_remaining%"
    line4: "&7Click to spectate"
  update_interval: 20  # Update every second

  cost: 100
  template:
    line1: "&6[Premium Game]"
    line2: "&7Cost: $100"

    line4: "%arena_players%/%arena_maxPlayers%"

docs.text:
# Different signs for different ranks
rank_based_signs:
  member:
    permission: "server.member"
    arenas: ["casual1", "casual2"]
  vip:
    permission: "server.vip"  
    arenas: ["vip_arena", "premium_stadium"]
  admin:
    permission: "server.admin"
    arenas: ["all"]

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text: Problem Cause Solution Sign doesn't work Command not executed properly Re-run the sign command and right-click again Wrong text displaying Configuration not reloaded Use /blockballsign reload Players can't click Missing permissions Check player has blockball.command Sign breaks functionality Incorrect arena name Verify arena exists with /blockball list

docs.title: Verify Sign Functionality
docs.text:
1. Check arena exists: /blockball list
  2. Test with admin: Right-click as administrator
  3. Check permissions: Ensure players have required permissions
  4. Monitor console: Look for error messages

docs.title: Debug Information
docs.text:
# Test arena accessibility
/blockball join <arena_name>

# Check player permissions
/lp user <player> permission check blockball.command

# Verify sign configuration
# Check files in /plugins/BlockBall/sign/

docs.title: Design Guidelines
docs.text:
User Experience

  • Clear labeling: Make sign purposes obvious
  • Consistent styling: Use the same color scheme across signs
  • Strategic placement: Put signs where players naturally look
  • Provide feedback: Use sounds and particles for interactions

Performance

  • Limit updates: Don't update signs too frequently
  • Group similar signs: Use consistent templates to reduce file size
  • Monitor usage: Remove unused signs to reduce server load

docs.title: Maintenance
docs.text:
Regular Checks

  • Test functionality: Verify signs work after plugin updates
  • Update designs: Refresh sign appearance for events or seasons
  • Check permissions: Ensure player access remains correct
  • Monitor logs: Watch for sign-related errors

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
Access Control

  • Limit sign creation: Only allow trusted staff to create signs
  • Validate arenas: Ensure signs point to existing, working arenas
  • Permission boundaries: Don't give players access beyond their rank

This sign system provides a professional, user-friendly interface that makes BlockBall accessible to all players regardless of their command knowledge!
